item.description:
Both August 26 and August 27 showings have SOLD OUT, so the MFA has added a September 2 showing of what appears to be a powerful tribute to the events of 9/11/2001.  

I failed to secure a ticket for the August 27 event, and also failed to encourage everyone who RSVP'd to secure a ticket in advance.  Yes, as my mantra is always ' get your tickets in advance before you RSVP', I can't believe I didn't foresee that this is going to be a special, sold out event.

So, I have purchased my ticket for September 2.  Please purchase your ticket as soon as possible as this event WILL SELL OUT:

http://www.mfa.org/programs/film/rebirth-2

I hope that everyone who RSVP'd for August 27 can switch to September 2, I apologize for idiotically assuming we could purchase tickets on the day of the event, and I hope to see you at the movie.

John

 

Rebirth  by James Whitaker (2011, 104 min.). This documentary chronicles the lives of five people deeply affected by and coping with the disastrous aftermath of 9/11, including a survivor, firefighter, and those who lost family members. The participants have given interviews on each anniversary of 9/11 and have invited the film crew to record relevant events in their lives. This emotional and moving footage is paired with stunning time-lapse footage of the reconstruction of Ground Zero. The overall vision is a compelling film experience and a unique historical record and resource: a living testament to honor 9/11, and its victims and heroes. “The word ‘inspiring’ gets overused but Rebirth is really and truly inspiring” (Kirk Honeycutt, The Hollywood Reporter).

Panel discussion follows screenings.

Project Rebirth:  http://www.projectrebirth.org/

From early 2002 through 2009, the  REBIRTH film crew chronicled the lives of five people directly affected by 9/11.  REBIRTH  also simultaneously tracks - via unprecedented multi-camera time-lapse photography - the evolution of the former  WTC and the entire rebuilding of the site.

Proceeds from the film will be used to seed a global resource for trauma preparation and response.

 

As we approach the 10th anniversary of the moment that changed the world, I've been anxious to do something to commemorate.  I want to recapture the feeling of togetherness that immediately followed, the possibility that a bitterly divided America evident in Bush V. Gore would come together in a way that we'd be able to look back and say that the world changed for the better.

Instead, we've lost more lives waging two wars perversely using 9/11 as justification.  We've become a country that condones torture, perversely using 9/11 as justification.  We've become a nation that allowed the rich to become obscenely rich, the middle class to lose millions of jobs, and children and senior citizens to go without food, health care, education, or hope.

The song "I'm proud to be an American, where at least I know I'm free" makes me sick to my stomach.

Rebirth premiers across the nation on Friday, August 26.  i'm going to the MFA on Saturday afternoon, August 27, knowing that the proceeds all go to Project Rebirth.  I expect to cry for the individual loss of life, for all that America and the world has lost, and for all the personal loss suffered from that tragic day.   I also expect to hope.  Maybe this anniversary will remind us that yes, we can build bridges with the rest of the world, we can ensure that each american has health, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness as a constitutional right, and we return to the spirit embodied in JFK's proclamation 'from this day forth'.

I hope you can join me experience this national commemoration.  Like the British '7 Up' series, this promises to be an amazing bit of film-making that took 10 years to complete.  After the film, we'll go to a nearby restaurant for discussion about the film, how 9/11 has affected each of our lives, and how 9/11/11 might accomplish what 9/11 did not.

See you at the movies,

John
item.how_to_find_us: John will organize meeting up both before the film. Panel discussion follows the film, after which we'll go to Pizzeria Uno for discussion.
